comment: PMID:24408435 All analyzed embryos were derived from 4  to 8  week-old  CAST/EiJ  (CAST) females mated to C57BL/6J (C57) males..Embryos  at  different  stages  of preimplantation   development   were   collected   at   defined   time   periods   after   hCG administration: 20–24 h after hCG (zygotes), 31–32 h (early 2-cell), 39-40 h (mid 2-cell), 46–48 h (late 2-cell), 54–56 h (4-cell), 68–70 h (8-cell), 76–78 h (16-cell), 86–88 h (early blastocysts),  92–94  h  (mid  blastocysts),  and  100–102  h  (late  blastocysts).  The  isolated embryos were further selected and assigned to appropriate samples based on cell numbers (up   to   16-cell   stage)   or   morphology   (blastocysts)...To isolate individual cells from embryos, we first removed the zona pellucida using acid  Tyrode’s  solution  (Sigma),  and  washed  embryos  twice  with  M 2  medium  (Sigma). We  then  used  TrypLE  (Invitrogen)  to  dissociate  embryos  into  single  cells. Incubation time  varied  from  30  seconds  to  5  minutes  depending  on  the  embryonic  stage.  For dissociation  of  blastocyst  embryos,  we  applied  an  additional  mechanical  di ssociation  by mouth pipetting, with a finely pulled glass capillary following TrypLE digestion. Single cells  were  washed  with  DMEM/F12  medium  (Invitrogen)  before  manually  picked  into hypotonic  Smart-seq  lysis  buffer.  We  either  directly  prepared  Smart-seq  cDNA  libraries or snap-froze samples on dry ice and kept at -80°C for future preparation.

Single cells  were  washed  with  DMEM/F12  medium  (Invitrogen)  before  manually  picked  into hypotonic  Smart-seq  lysis  buffer.  We  either  directly  prepared  Smart-seq  cDNA  libraries or snap-froze samples on dry ice and kept at -80°C for future preparation.

Paper PMID:29126398 dataset of mouse embryos (GEO accession: GSE45719), in which 42 F1 embryos of two mouse strains, CAST/Ei and C57BL/6, at 10 stages, including zygote, early 2-cell, middle 2-cell, later 2-cell, 4-cell, 8-cell, 16-cell, early blast, middle blast and later blast stages, were used to determine the expression of maternal and paternal alleles; Paper PMID:24408435 the  8-cell,  mid-blastocyst  and  late-blastocyst  stages  as  by  chance  only  male  embryos  were  sampled  for these stages

PMID:24408435 All analyzed embryos were derived from 4  to 8  week-old  CAST/EiJ  (CAST) females mated to C57BL/6J (C57) males..Embryos  at  different  stages  of preimplantation   development   were   collected   at   defined   time   periods   after   hCG administration: 20–24 h after hCG (zygotes), 31–32 h (early 2-cell), 39-40 h (mid 2-cell), 46–48 h (late 2-cell), 54–56 h (4-cell), 68–70 h (8-cell), 76–78 h (16-cell), 86–88 h (early blastocysts),  92–94  h  (mid  blastocysts),  and  100–102  h  (late  blastocysts).  The  isolated embryos were further selected and assigned to appropriate samples based on cell numbers (up   to   16-cell   stage)   or   morphology   (blastocysts)...To isolate individual cells from embryos, we first removed the zona pellucida using acid  Tyrode’s  solution  (Sigma),  and  washed  embryos  twice  with  M 2  medium  (Sigma). We  then  used  TrypLE  (Invitrogen)  to  dissociate  embryos  into  single  cells. Incubation time  varied  from  30  seconds  to  5  minutes  depending  on  the  embryonic  stage.  For dissociation  of  blastocyst  embryos,  we  applied  an  additional  mechanical  di ssociation  by mouth pipetting, with a finely pulled glass capillary following TrypLE digestion. Single cells  were  washed  with  DMEM/F12  medium  (Invitrogen)  before  manually  picked  into hypotonic  Smart-seq  lysis  buffer.  We  either  directly  prepared  Smart-seq  cDNA  libraries or snap-froze samples on dry ice and kept at -80°C for future preparation.

PMID:30283141 Isolating viable single cells from both pancreas and liver of the same mouse was not possible, therefore, 2 males and 2 females were used for each. Whole organs were then dissected in the following order: large intestine, spleen, thymus, trachea, tongue, brain, heart, lung, kidney, gonadal adipose tissue (GAT), bladder, diaphragm, limb muscle (tibialis anterior), skin (dorsal), subcutaneous adipose tissue (SCAT, inguinal pad), mammary glands (fat pads 2, 3, and 4), brown adipose tissue (BAT, interscapular pad), aorta, and bone marrow (spine and limb bones). Following single cell dissociation as described below, cell suspensions were either used for FACS of individual cells into 384-well plates, or for microfluidic droplet library preparation./https://figshare.com/articles/Single-cell_RNA-seq_data_from_microfluidic_emulsion/5715025 for sex information

Following single cell dissociation as described below, cell suspensions were either used for FACS of individual cells into 384-well plates, or for microfluidic droplet library preparation./https://figshare.com/articles/Single-cell_RNA-seq_data_from_microfluidic_emulsion/5715025 for sex information

PMID:26060301 We used single cell RNA sequencing to interrogate the heterogeneity of the adult human cortex in an approach that combines transcriptome-wide analysis with single cell resolution. Brain tissue was obtained from living subjects who underwent temporal lobectomy for medically refractory seizures and mesial temporal sclerosis (MTS). In these patients, a small piece (0.5–3 g) of anterior temporal lobe was resected during the surgical approach to deeper areas of the brain and was considered normal by all detectable means including electroencephalogram (EEG) and pathological examination. We also performed a set of experiments with cortex from prenatal brain at the age of 16–18 weeks postgestation.

In these patients, a small piece (0.5–3 g) of anterior temporal lobe was resected during the surgical approach to deeper areas of the brain and was considered normal by all detectable means including electroencephalogram (EEG) and pathological examination. We also performed a set of experiments with cortex from prenatal brain at the age of 16–18 weeks postgestation.

In these patients, a small piece (0.5–3 g) of anterior temporal lobe was resected during the surgical approach to deeper areas of the brain and was considered normal by all detectable means including electroencephalogram (EEG) and pathological examination. We also performed a set of experiments with cortex from prenatal brain at the age of 16–18 weeks postgestation.

PMID:28965763 To investigate the effect of physiological aging on pancreatic epithelial cells, we obtained pancreata from eight previously healthy donors operationally defined as juvenile (ages 1 month, 5 years, and 6 years), young adult (ages 21 years and 22 years), and adult/middle aged (ages 38 years, 44 years, and 54 years). Single pancreatic cells were purified by flow cytometry and their mRNA expression analyzed using scRNA-seq (Picelli et al., 2014) with transcript abundance expressed as counts per million (CPM) and the quality of individual cells assessed using an automated quality control pipeline (see STAR Methods for details); suppl.data Table 1 donor info
